prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: omi Ceti, 28SiO, Band 7, J=7-6, v=0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main line: SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~20 Jy from Wittkowski in prep) Also includes: 30SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~10 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) 30SiO J=7-6 v=2 (~10 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) Continuum band to probe Mira A and B and the dust environment. Peak continuum 470 mJy measured by ACA in band 7 (Ramstedt et al.), unresolved by ACA.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Main line: SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~20 Jy from Wittkowski in prep) Also includes: 30SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~10 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) 30SiO J=7-6 v=2 (~10 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) Continuum band to detect Mira A and B, and the dust.
The v=0 thermal lines have a width of about 10 km/sec. The v=1,2 maser lines break down into several components of typically 1 Jy, a width of 1 km/sec, and velocity offsets of a few km/sec.
Our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is needed to sample the individual maser lines and to detect a possible contribution/contamination by individual maser components in the v=0 line.
The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas.
The omi Ceti peak continuum flux was measured by AKA in band 7 to 470 mJy by Ramstedt et al. (unresolved). Matthews and Karovska (2006) showed that both Mira A and Mira B have positive spectral indices and are likely predominantly thermal sources. Taking their spectral flux index and extrapolating to 100 GHz (3mm), we obtain flux densities of 9 mJy and 2.3 mJy for the two components. Supposing that they become optically thin around 100 GHz, the flux density of Mira B may still be around 2 mJy at 300 GHz.
Our continuum sensitivity with the aggregate bandwidth, thanks to the continuum baseband used, will be around 0.2 mJy, so that both Mira A and Mira B will be detected (note that the sensitivity in the OT is based on the reperesentative window resolution for the lines, and not on the aggregate bandwidth).
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: omi Ceti, 29SiO, Band 7, J=7-6, v=0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main line: 29SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~10 Jy from Wittkowski in prep) Also includes: SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~30 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) SiO J=7-6 v=2 (~30 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) Continuum band to probe Mira A and B and the dust environment. Peak continuum 470 mJy measured by ACA in band 7 (Ramstedt et al.).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Main line: 29SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~10 Jy from Wittkowski in prep) Also includes: SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~30 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~30 Jy from 29SiO J=7-6 by APEX, Wittkowski in prep) Continuum band to detect Mira A and B, and the dust.
The v=0 thermal lines have a width of about 10 km/sec. The v=1,2 maser lines break down into several components of typically 1 Jy, a width of 1 km/sec, and velocity offsets of a few km/sec.
Our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is needed to sample the individual maser lines and to detect a possible contribution/contamination by individual maser components in the v=0 line.
The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas.
The omi Ceti peak continuum flux was measured by AKA in band 7 to 470 mJy by Ramstedt et al. (unresolved). Matthews and Karovska (2006) showed that both Mira A and Mira B have positive spectral indices and are likely predominantly thermal sources. Taking their spectral flux index and extrapolating to 100 GHz (3mm), we obtain flux densities of 9 mJy and 2.3 mJy for the two components. Supposing that they become optically thin around 100 GHz, the flux density of Mira B may still be around 2 mJy at 300 GHz.
Our continuum sensitivity with the aggregate bandwidth, thanks to the continuum baseband used, will be around 0.2 mJy, so that both Mira A and Mira B will be detected (note that the sensitivity in the OT is based on the reperesentative window resolution for the lines, and not on the aggregate bandwidth).
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: omi Ceti, 30SiO, Band 7, J=7-6, v=0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main line: 30SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~10 Jy from APEX, Wittkowski in prep) Also includes: SiO J=7-6 v=3 (~5 Jy from APEX, Wittkowski in prep) TiO2 (21(1,21)-20(0,20), 284.37 GHz, ~100mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) TiO (9-8) 284.88 GHz, 240 mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013). Peak continuum 470 mJy measured by ACA in band 7 (Ramstedt et al.).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Main line: 30SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~10 Jy from APEX, Wittkowski in prep) Also includes: SiO J=7-6 v=3 (~5 Jy from APEX, Wittkowski in prep). TiO2 (21(1,21)-20(0,20), 284.37 GHz, ~100mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. 2013. TiO (9-8) 284.88 GHz, 240 mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. 2013.
The v=0 thermal lines have a width of 10 km/sec. The v=1,2 maser lines break down into several components of typically 1 Jy, a width of 1 km/sec, and velocity offsets of a few km/sec.
Our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is needed to sample the individual maser lines and to detect a possible contribution/contamination by individual maser components in the v=0 line.
The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas.
The TiO and TiO2 lines are measured to have a peak flux density of ~200 mJy in VY CMa by Kaminski et al. (2013), and are thus fainter by a factor of 60-100 compared to the SiO v=0 lines. They will thus be detectable with our sensitivity of ~20 mJy. Their width is similar to that of the SiO v=0 lines, and our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is adequate to resolve outflow velocities of a few km/sec.
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: omi Ceti, 28SiO, Band 7, J=8-7, v=0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main line: SiO, J=8-7, v=0 (~20 Jy based on 7-6 from APEX, Wittkowski, in prep) Also includes: TiO2 (24(2,22)-23(3,21), 347.79 GHz, ~150mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) TiO (11-10) 348.16 GHz, 440 mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) Continuum band to probe Mira A and B and the dust environment. Peak continuum 470 mJy measured by ACA in band 7 (Ramstedt et al.).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Main line: SiO, J=8-7, v=0 (~20 Jy based on 7-6 from APEX, Wittkowski in prep) Also includes: TiO2 (24(2,22)-23(3,21), 347.79 GHz, ~150mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) TiO (11-10) 348.16 GHz, 440 mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) Continuum
The v=0 thermal lines have a width of 10 km/sec. The v=1,2 maser lines break down into several components of typically 1 Jy, a width of 1 km/sec, and velocity offsets of a few km/sec.
Our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is needed to sample the individual maser lines and to detect a possible contribution/contamination by individual maser components in the v=0 line.
The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas.
The TiO and TiO2 lines are measured to have a peak flux density of ~200 mJy in VY CMa by Kaminski et al. (2013), and are thus fainter by a factor of 60-100 compared to the SiO v=0 lines. They will thus be detectable with our sensitivity of ~20 mJy. Their width is similar to that of the SiO v=0 lines, and our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is adequate to resolve outflow velocities of a few km/sec.
The omi Ceti peak continuum flux was measured by AKA in band 7 to 470 mJy by Ramstedt et al. (unresolved). Matthews and Karovska (2006) showed that both Mira A and Mira B have positive spectral indices and are likely predominantly thermal sources. Taking their spectral flux index and extrapolating to 100 GHz (3mm), we obtain flux densities of 9 mJy and 2.3 mJy for the two components. Supposing that they become optically thin around 100 GHz, the flux density of Mira B may still be around 2 mJy at 300 GHz.
Our continuum sensitivity with the aggregate bandwidth, thanks to the continuum baseband used, will be around 0.2 mJy, so that both Mira A and Mira B will be detected (note that the sensitivity in the OT is based on the reperesentative window resolution for the lines, and not on the aggregate bandwidth).
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: VY CMa, 28SiO, Band 7, J=7-6, v=0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main line: SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~30 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) Also includes: 30SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~20 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) 30SiO J=7-6 v=2 (~20 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) Continuum band to probe the dust envelope. Peak continuum 300 mJy measured by Muller et al. (2007).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Main line: SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~30 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) Also includes: 30SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~20 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) 30SiO J=7-6 v=2 (~20 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) Continuum band to probe the dust envelope. Peak continuum 300 mJy measured by Muller et al. (2007).
The flux values are estimated based on the J=7-6, v=1,2 values measured by Humphreys et al. (1997) and scaled to other lines based on omi Ceti APEX measurements by Wittkowski et al. (in prep).
The v=0 thermal lines have a width of about 10 km/sec. The v=1,2 maser lines break down into several components of typically 1 Jy, a width of 1 km/sec, and velocity offsets of a few km/sec.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.
Our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is needed to sample the individual maser lines and to detect a possible contribution/contamination by individual maser components in the v=0 line.
The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas.
Using the SMA (1.4 arcsec resolution), Muller et al. (2007) found the 1.3mm continuum was unresolved and well-fit by a point source of 288 +- 25 mJy, ~10 mJy of which is believed to be stellar blackbody emission. Our continuum sensitivity with the aggregate bandwidth, thanks to the continuum baseband used, will be around 0.2 mJy, so that the stellar continuum source as well as the close dust environment will be detected (note that the sensitivity in the OT is based on the reperesentative window resolution for the lines, and not on the aggregate bandwidth).
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: VY CMa, 29SiO, Band 7, J=7-6, v=0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main line: 29SiO, J=7-6, v=0 (~15 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) Also includes: SiO J=7-6 v=1 (~40 Jy, Humphreys et al. 1997) SiO J=7-6 v=2 (~40 Jy, Humphreys et al. 1997) Continuum band to probe the dust environment. Peak continuum 300 mJy measured by Muller et al. (2007).

The flux values are estimated based on the J=7-6, v=1,2 values measured by Humphreys et al. (1997) and scaled to other lines based on omi Ceti APEX measurements by Wittkowski et al. (in prep).
The v=0 thermal lines have a width of about 10 km/sec. The v=1,2 maser lines break down into several components of typically 1 Jy, a width of 1 km/sec, and velocity offsets of a few km/sec.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.
Our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is needed to sample the individual maser lines and to detect a possible contribution/contamination by individual maser components in the v=0 line.
The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas. Using the SMA (1.4 arcsec resolution), Muller et al. (2007) found the 1.3mm continuum was unresolved and well-fit by a point source of 288 +- 25 mJy, ~10 mJy of which is believed to be stellar blackbody emission. Our continuum sensitivity with the aggregate bandwidth, thanks to the continuum baseband used, will be around 0.2 mJy, so that the stellar continuum source as well as the close dust environment will be detected (note that the sensitivity in the OT is based on the reperesentative window resolution for the lines, and not on the aggregate bandwidth).
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.

(2013) TiO (9-8) 284.88 GHz, 240 mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) Peak continuum 300 mJy measured by Muller et al. (2007).

The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas.
The TiO and TiO2 lines are measured to have a peak flux density of ~200 mJy in VY CMa by Kaminski et al. (2013). They will thus be detectable with our sensitivity of ~20 mJy. Their width is similar to that of the SiO v=0 lines, and our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is adequate to resolve outflow velocities of a few km/sec.
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Main line: SiO, J=8-7, v=0 (~30 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) Also includes: TiO2 (24(2,22)-23(3,21), 347.79 GHz, ~150mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) TiO (11-10) 348.16 GHz, 440 mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) Continuum band to probe the dust environment. Peak continuum 300 mJy measured by Muller et al. (2007).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Main line: SiO, J=8-7, v=0 (~30 Jy based on Humphreys et al. 1997) Also includes: TiO2 (24(2,22)-23(3,21), 347.79 GHz, ~150mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) TiO (11-10) 348.16 GHz, 440 mJy in VY CMa, Kaminski et al. (2013) Continuum band to probe the dust environment. Peak continuum 300 mJy measured by Muller et al. (2007).
The SiO flux values are estimated based on the J=7-6, v=1,2 values measured by Humphreys et al. (1997) and scaled to other lines based on omi Ceti APEX measurements by Wittkowski et al. (in prep).
The v=0 thermal lines have a width of 10 km/sec. The v=1,2 maser lines break down into several components of typically 1 Jy, a width of 1 km/sec, and velocity offsets of a few km/sec.
Our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is needed to sample the individual maser lines and to detect a possible contribution/contamination by individual maser components in the v=0 line.
The requested sensitivity was determined to reach high signal-to-noise of both the thermal and maser SiO emission. We will gain a S/N on individual maser components of ~60, leading to a relative position accuracy of beamsize/(2*SNR) of ~1.3 mas.
The TiO and TiO2 lines are measured to have a peak flux density of ~200 mJy in VY CMa by Kaminski et al. (2013). They will thus be detectable with our sensitivity of ~20 mJy. Their width is similar to that of the SiO v=0 lines, and our velocity resolution of 0.1-0.2km/sec is adequate to resolve outflow velocities of a few km/sec.
Using the SMA (1.4 arcsec resolution), Muller et al. (2007) found the 1.3mm continuum was unresolved and well-fit by a point source of 288 +- 25 mJy, ~10 mJy of which is believed to be stellar blackbody emission. Our continuum sensitivity with the aggregate bandwidth, thanks to the continuum baseband used, will be around 0.2 mJy, so that the stellar continuum source as well as the close dust environment will be detected (note that the sensitivity in the OT is based on the reperesentative window resolution for the lines, and not on the aggregate bandwidth).
Note that the execution time is dominated by overheads and that a lower sensitivity would gain only a few minutes.
Note that we tried other spw combinations, but that there was little improvement in efficiency, as we need a high spectral resolution to detect maser components, and a wide bandwidth for continuum subtraction and because of the high velocity outflows in some thermal lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Although red giant and supergiant stars are the main sources of dust in the galaxies, we do yet not understand well the dust formation and mass-loss processes from these stars. Shaping processes in their environments contribute to the mass-loss process and are also being investigated.
With ALMA we propose to deepen our understanding of these objects by measuring the radial structure and morphology of the SiO emitting regions up to a few arcsec toward two well-studied mass-losing stars, the Mira variable o Ceti and the red supergiant VY CMa.
SiO is located between about a few tens of milli-arcsec to a few arcsec, beyond the atmospheric regions, which can be traced by infrared interferometry, but well inside typical CO radii. This enlaces silicate dust formation and acceleration regions that can otherwise not be probed. Our setup also includes TiO and TiO2 lines, which are thought to be important seed particles for dust formation, as well as the continuum, which will allow us to detect the stellar components of VY CMa and Mira A and B, as well as the dust continuum.
The proposed ALMA observations complement our infrared interferometry and APEX monitoring of the same sources.
